titleStmt.author: Montulmo, Antonius de.

titleStmt.title: An almanacke and prognosticacion for the yere of our Lord God D.CCCCC.LV. [sic] Made by Master Antonius de Mortulind, an Italian, doctoure of phisicke and astronymy.
titleStmt.author: Montulmo, Antonius de.

publicationStmt.publisher: By Thomas Marche, dwellinge in Fletestrete, at the sygne of the Princes armes,

notesStmt.note: The compiler is called "Motulind" on the title page and "Motulmo" on the prognostication title page--Cf. STC.
Identified as STC 487 on UMI microfilm.
Imperfect; title page of prognostication (2nd A1) lacking.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-05 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-07 John PasText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: For the yere of our Lord God D.CCCCC.LV. Made by Maſter Antonius de Motulino, an Italian, Doctoure of Phiſicke. and Aſtronymy.
¶Imprynted at London, by Thomas Marche, dwellinge in Flete ſtrete, at the ſygne of the Princes armes.

div.head: ¶ A declaracion of the Almanacke.
div.p: ¶The Golden number. xvii.
¶The Sondaye letter. F
¶Betwene Chriſtmas and ſhrofiyde. viii. wekes and .v dayes.
¶ Septage ſima the .x. of February.
¶ Aſhewenyſday the .xxvii. of February.
¶ Eaſter day the .xviiii. of Apryll.
¶ Croſſe dayes the xix. of Maye.
¶ Aſcencion daye the .xxiii. of Maye.
¶ Wytſonday the .ii. of Iune.
¶ Corpus Chriſty daye the .xiii. of Iune.
¶ Aduent the fyrſt day of December.

¶ To take diſgeſtiues and preparaſyues wherby is made thinne or reſolued any groſſe hinnor, that it maye the lightlier be purged by the Phiſycke or Surgery, within the body or wythout, the Mone beyng ſornaite in Gemini, Libra. or Aquarius.
¶ To purge by electuaries, the Mone beynge illuſtrated wyth Iupiter or Venus, and in Cancer is very good.
¶ To purge by drynkes. Scorpio.
¶To purge by pylles. Piſces.
¶To take clyſters. Libra, and Scorpio.
¶To let bloude. Cancer, Scorpio, Piſces To take vomites, Aries, Taurꝰ, Capricornꝰ.

¶To take Gargariſnies, Aries, Cancer,
Capricornus.
¶To enter into bathe, the Mone beynge in the trine or ſextyle aſpect of Sol or Mars, in theſe ſygnes of Cancer, Scorpio, Piſces is very good.
¶To cut heyres, when the Mone is in Libra. Sagitarius, Aquarius, Piſces, it is good and eſpecially yf ſhe be at a tryne aſpect or els a ſextyle wyth Mars and Venus bothe.
¶To ſtoppe Flxes, Rewmes or Lares, it is good the Mone beyng at a tryne of Saturne in theſe ſygnes, Taurus, Virgo, Capricornus, or els at a ſextyle aſpecte with hym.

¶To comforte the vertue, attractyſe that euery member may drawe vnto him his ſuſtenaunce and lykynge, it is good the Mone beynge at a tryne aſpect wyth Sol and Iupiter in theſe ſignes, Aries, Leo, Sagittarius.
¶To ſet, ſowe, plant, or graſſe, it .s good the Mone beynge at a tryne aſpecte, or els or a ſextyle of Saturne, and in theſe ſygnes Virgo, Taurus, and Capricornus.
¶This yere ſhall be a dredfull Eclypſe of the Mone the .v. of Iune at .ii. a clocke in the mornynge, and ſhe ſhall be all darkened.

row.cell: Son riſyng houres and minutes after,

div.p: ❍ The full mone at .vii. of the clocke .35. minutes after none fayre and wyndy.
☾ The laſte quarter at .xii. a clocke at nyghte the .xv. daye with rayne and wynde the moſte of the quarter.
● The newe mone the .xxii. daye at one of the clocke at after mydnyghte, and .xlii. minutes after, rayne and wynde the moſt par • e of this quarter,
☽The fyrſte quarter the .xxix daye at .v. of the clocke in the after noone temporate, fayre wyth froſte.
❍ The full mone the .vi. daye at .ii. of the clock at after none, and .iiii. mynutes after fayre wether wyth an inclinacion alſo to moyſture withall.
❍ The full moone the .xiii. daye at .iiii. of the clocke in the after none enclyned to wynde with moiſture the weather.
● The newe mone the .xxi. day, at xxiiii. minutes, after .xi. of the clocke in the fore none fayre whether.
☽ The fyrſt quarter at .vi. of the clocke in the mornynge the .xxviii. daye fayre wether and drye.
❍ The full Moone the .viii. daye at ſeuen a clocke .xii. minutes after, moſt of the quarter cloudy coulde and rayny.
☾ The laſte quarter of the Mone at .vi. of the clocke in the mornynge the .xvi. daye aboue wrytten in the begynnynge fayre, and towardes the latter ende raynye and cloudye wether.
● The newe mone the .xxii. daye at eyghte at the clocke at nyghte, and .xx. minutes after in the begynnynge of the quarter wyndye and fayre wether, after rayny and cloudye.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxix. day at .ix. of the the clocke of the night fayre wether and wyndy moſt part of the quarter ſpeciallye in the begynnynge therof.
❍The full Mone at .xii. of the clocke .xl. minutes at after mydnight the .vi. daye of this moneth aboue wrytten inclyned to moyſture in the begynnynge, and ſo fayre wether at the ende.
☾ The laſte quarter the .xiii daye at .iii. of the clocke in the afternone cloudy, in the begynnynge of the quarter, and fayre at the latter ende.
●The chaunge of the moone the .xxi. daye in the begynnynge inclyned to moyſture ſo almoſt all the quarter.
☽ The fyrſte quarter at .i. of the clocke at after none fayre wether.

row.cell: ſonne ſettynge hou • es mynutes after,

div.p: ❍ The full Mone at .ii. of the clocke in the afternone, and .xlix. minutes after ſhoures.
☾ The laſte quarter the .xiii. daye at i • . of the clocke at mydnyghte wyndy, and inclyned to moyſture.
● The newe Mone the .xx. daye at .ii. of the clocks, at after none .xiiii. minutes after cloudy and cloſe wether.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxviii. daye at .vi. of the clocke in the mornynge fayre wether and hote.
❍ The full Moone at .ii. of the clocke in the mornynge, and .xxxii. minutes after, the .v. day fayre wether.
☾ The laſte quarter the .xi. daye at mydnyghte moſt of the quarter cloudy and rayny.
● The newe Mone the .xviii. daye .xxxiiii. mynutes after mydnyghte, moſte of the quarter ſhoures and rayne, and muche cloudy wether.
☽The fyrſte quarter the .xxvi. daye at .xi. of the clocke at night that day cloudy, and inclined to rayne with hayle, and fayre we • her, and wyndy moſt part of the quarter.
❍ The full mone the .iiii. day at none, and .xx. minutes after fayre wether mooſte of this quarter.
☾ The laſte quarter at .iiii. of the clocke in the mornynge the .xi. daye wyndye and temperate cloudy wether.
● The newe mone .xliiii. minutes after hyghe none the .xviii. day cloudye and cloſe wether the next daye, but the .xviii. daye fayre wether and ſo moſt of the quarter.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxvi. daye at .iii. of the clocke in the after none wyndy and fayre wether.
❍The full mone the .ii. daye at eyghte of the clocke at nyght, & .lvii. minutes after fayre wether, & hoo • e moſt of the quarter with lyghtnynge the .iii. daye of the moneth.
☾ The laſt quarter the .ix. day at .xi. of ye clocke before none faire wether that day, but moſt of the reſt of the quarter cloudy & moyſt wether.
● The newe mone the .xvii. daye at .v. of the clocke in the mornynge, and .viii. minutes afterfayre wether and wyndy.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxv. day at .vi. of the clockem the mornynge cloudye and inclyned to rayne.
❍ The full mone the fyrſte daye at .v. of the clocke, and .xv. minutes fayre and wyndye weher.
☾ The laſt quarter the .vii. day at .ix. of the clocke at nyght, moſt of this quarter wyndy, and fayre temperate wéther.
● The newe Mone the .xv. daye at .vii. of the clocke at nyght, and .xl. minutes after cloudy and cloſe wether.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxii. daye at .viii. of the clocke at nyghte cloudye and colde wether.
❍ The full mone the .xxx. day at .i. of the clock in the after none and .lvii. minutes after fayre wether.
☾ The laſte quarter the .vii. daye at .xi of the clocke before none fayre wether, and ſomewhat cloudy withal ſome tymes.
● The newe mone the .xv. daye at one of the clocke in the after none, and .xxxiiii. minutes after fayre wether with whyte cloudes ſparkled about the heauen.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxiii day a • .ix. of the clocke of the day before none fayre wether.
❍ The full moone the .xxix. day at .xi. of the clocke at night, and xliiii. minutes after wyndy and cloudy with ſome rayne.

row.cell: Sonne ryſyng houres my nutes after.

div.p: ☾ The laſte quarter the .vi. daye at .iiii. of the clocke in the mornynge fa •• wether and a froſt at nyght, but moſt of the reſt of the quarter ſwete dryllynge rayne.
● The newe mone the .xiiii. daye at .vii. of the clocke in the mornynge, and .xxxvi. minutes after cloudy wether.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxi. day at .vi. of the clocke at nyght fayre wether.
❍ The full mone the .xxviii daye at .xi. of the clocke before none wyndy with whyte cloudes ſparkled about the heauen.
☾ The laſte quarter the .v. daye at mydnyghte and .iiii. minutes after fayre and colde, and drye wether.
●The new mone the .xiii. daye at mydnyghte, and .xxii. minutes after in the begynnyng cloudy and very colde, and the reſt of the quarter and the moſt part the ſame wether.
☽ The fyrſte quarter the .xxi. day at .iii. of the clocke in the mornynge the fyrſte quarter fayre wether.
❍ The full mone the .xxvii. day at mydnyghte and .xxxiii. minutes after, rayne with wynde and miſty wether.

FOr aſmuche, as God whiche is the beginning of all Creatures, (good gentyle reader) hath made man to his own ſimilytude and lykenes, wherby he is almoſt comporable to the holy Aungels of god, who is it then, that wyll denye that man maye by the diſpoſition of the ſtarres, prognoſticate thinges to come, as (Becolus Chaldeus wryteth that holy Noe did vnto Armenians and Sethians after the vniuerſal deluge or floude, wherfore they called him the partaker of the mynde of God. Moreouer S. Hierome, wryteth, that what ſoeuer can be comprehended with humayne vnderſtanding is ruled by the wheles of the Sunne. wherefore in aſmuche as bothe the dyuine, and the Prince of Philoſophers, Ariſtotle in his booke (de generatione, et corruptione) confeſſeth that (propter acceſſum, et receſſum ſolis in curculo obliquo fiunt generationes, et corrupſiones in mundo ſublunati.) It foloweth that knowynge the diſpoſicion of the celeſtial bodies, by the whiche all ementate bodyes be ruled, that we men maye by the ſcience of Aſtronimy (whiche ſcyence
Petrus Caneracentis calleth worthily naturall theologie (prognoſticating as is aforeſayde thynges to come, as mutacions of the ayre, peſtilencis, & al other infirmities, war, penury, peace, or plenty of victuals, which depende of the heauens, as ſeconde cauſes of God, to ſuche effectes appoynted, wherefore (good gentyl reader) the premyſſes beynge well penſed, I deſyre the not to take all thynges that ſhall be Prognoſticated in this yeres Prognoſticacion as contigences of fatal neceſſity, but that it ſhal chaunce, yf God do not forbyd, thus I bydde thee well to fare.

div.head: ¶ The particular declaracion of the wether for this preſent yeare. (Anno domini. M.LLLLL.L.V.
¶ Ianuary.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day in the after none rayne and windy, the ſeconde daye rayne all the after noone, and at night alſo the thirde daye ruddy cloudes, with blackneſſe myngled with al, and rain the fourthe daye in the afternoone, and after great rayne, and almoſt all the nyghte longe, rayne alſo, the fyfte daye towardes nyghte fayre weather, but the daye aforeſayde ſhalbe rayne, becauſe of the Sextyle aſpect of Soll to Saturne, they bothe beynge in moſte manſions, the ſyxte daye ſome what enclyned to rayne, the ſeuenth day ſomwhat ruddye cloudes, & blackenes myngled wyth them, brynging ſome rayne. The eyght daye fayre wether, and toward night windy, and rayne. The .ix. daye rainye. The tenth daye in the after noone fayre, and ſomewhat wyndye. The eleuenth day at after noone rayne.
The twelueth in the mornyng fayre wether. The thirtene at after noone rayne The fourtenth a temperate daye, the fyftenth a fayre daye in the afternoone but about the fore noone, and the nyght afore rayne, and windye weather ſhalbe, the ſyxtene ſomewhat enclined to rayne the .xvii. in the mornynge ſomwhat fayre but red cloudes couerynge the heauens, ſhal bring ſome rayne afternoone. The xvii. day, becauſe of the quart aſpecte of Iupiter and Mercurius, ſhalbe verye windy, the nynetene daye ſomwhat driſſe lynge, and rainy, the .xx. daye whyte and reade cloudes, bringing with them ſhouers of rayn, the one and twenty the ſame wether, the .xxii. daye windy and fayre, in the fore none the .xxiii. day cold and moiſt the .xxiiii. daye blacke cloudes, rayne and wyndes alſo, the .xxv. day cold and rainy, becauſe of the corporall coniuncion of Saturnus and Venus, in the ſygne of Piſces, the twenty and ſyxe daye colde and moyeſt, the twenty and ſeuen daye towardes nyght rayne, and ſome wyndines in the ayre, the twenty and eight day windy and fayre wether, the .xxix. day fair wether, the thirty day rayne, and blacke cloudes with cold weather.

div.head: ¶ February.
div.p:
THe, fyrſte daye coulde and moyſte, The ſeconde daye ſomewhat enclyned to moyſture, the third daye in the after noone ſomewhat fayre, but at nyght, and ſpecially after midnyghte wyndy, and ſomwhat enclyned to rayne, the fourthe afore noone, ſomewhat enclyned to moyſture, but after none fayre wether, the fyueth day rayne, ſpecially about noone, and at one of the clocke, becauſe of a Sextyle aſpect betwyxt Saturne, and Mercurius, the .vi. daye, becauſe of the appoſicion of Sol and Luna in Aquarius, and Leo, whiche be rainy ſynges rayne, the ſeuenth daye ſome what enclyned to moyſture, the eyghte daye a fayre day, becauſe of the coniunccion Corporall, of Luna and Mars, in Virgo a drye ſigne, the ninth daye rayne with wynde, the tenth daye very wyndye becauſe of the quarte aſpect of Mercurius to Iupiter retrograde, the eleuēth rayne with wynde, the twelueth wyndye and fayre whytyſhe Cloudes aboute the heauens, becauſe of the trinall aſpecte of Soll and Iupiter retrograde. The thyrtene daye in the mornyng fayre wether. The fourtenth at noone ſomewhat
enclyned to moieſture, and after none more enclyned to rain then afore. The fyftene daye a fayre daye, and read dyſhe cloudes ſparkled aboute the heauens, the ſyxtene day about after none, rayne, the ſeuentene daie at after none fayre weather. The eyghtene at after noone rayne. The nynetene wyndye and rayne a litle, the twenty towardes night windye, the twenty and one, aboute eleuen of the clocke afore none rayne, but towardes nyght fayre weather, the .xxii. towardes nyghte, cloudye and raine, the xxiii. becauſe of the appoſicyon of Soll, and Mars, fayre weather, and red cloudes, bringing with them ſome rain, ſom times, the .xxiiii. becauſe of the coniunction of Saturne and Venus in the moiſt manſion colde wether and rain, the .xxv. daye farye weather. the .xxvi. daye rayne and wyndye the after noone. The .xxvii. daye ſomewhat fayre at afternone, and towardes nyght, the .xxviii. daye rayne.

div.head: ¶ Marche.
div.p:
THe fyrſte daye wyndy with a lytle dryſelynge rayne, the .ii. day ſomewhat rainy wether, the thyrde day rayny weather, the fourthe and .v. rayne becauſe of the coniunction corparall of
Venus and Sol, in the watery ſygne of Piſces, the .vi. day towards nyght fayre red cloudes, and wynde with a lytle raine the .vii. in the after noone ſomwhat temperate wether, the .viii. cloudy and moyſt wether, the .ix. temperate weather, the .x. daye whyte cloudes aboute the heauens ſparkled, the .xi. becauſe of the coniunccion of Venus and Mercurie in the watery ſigne of Piſces, rainy and wyndye, the .xii. alſo the ſame wether, the .xiii cloudye, colde weather, rayne and hayle, becauſe of the corporall coniuncion of Sol, and Saturnus that daye, the .xiiii. towardes night, and at nyghte rayne, the .xv. ſomwhat enclyned to rayne, the xvi. in the mornyng ſomewhat fayre wether, the .xvii. and .xviii. rainy wether, becauſe of the coniuncion of Saturne, and Mercury, the .xix. day ſomwhat fayre wether, the twenty day fayre wether, the .xxi in the mornynge rayne, becauſe of the coniuncion of Luna, and Venus in Piſces a watry ſygne, the .xxii. at mornynge cloudy, but it wyll breake vp at after noone, the xxiii. daye windye, ſpecially at nyghte, the .xxiiii. ſomewhat ruddye cloudy, bringinge with them ſome rayne the .xxv in the mornynge ſome driſſynge rayne, the .xxvi. aboute none, colde and
cloudy, the .xxvii. fayre before none, but in the after none it is lyke to rayne ſomwhat, but a lytle, the .xxviii. daye aboute none wyndy, but towardes nyghte there with cloudy, the .xxix. daye at after none a lytle rayne, the .xxx. daye aboute after none very windye, the .xxxi. daye greate wyndes, becauſe of the oppoſicion of Iupiter, and Mercuri.

div.head: ¶ Apryll.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day fayre, the ſecond day wyndy, and at after noone hot, the thyrde a fayre daye, but towardes nyght ſomewhat enclyned to rayne, the fourthe daye fayre, and temperate weather, becauſe of the coniuncion corporal of Iupiter and Luna, in Libra, an ayrye ſygne, the fyfte in the mornynge cloudy, the ſyxt a fayre daye, ſpecially in the after none, the ſeuenth daye, a fayre after none, and ſomwhat hotter then before, the eyght daye, and ſpecially in the mornynge windy, and after ſomewhat enclyned to coldneſſe, and moyſture in the after none, and the ſame nyghte alſo, the nynthe daye ſomewhat a fayre daye and very wyndy with whyte cloudes ſparkled about the heauens, becauſe of the oppoſicions of Soll, and Iupiter in a fyerye,
and ayrye ſygnes, the tenth in the mornynge cloudy, the eleuenth ſomwhat inclyned to rayne, the .xii. day, a fayre morning, but at afternone cold and cloudy, the .xiii. daye aboute afternone wyndy, the .xiiii about the ryſing of the ſonne fayre, and temperate, the .xv. fayre, and hotter then before becauſe of the trenal aſpect of Sol and Mars in year • hly ſignes, the .xvi. in the mornyng wyndye, and after none fayre, and ſomewhat hotter then before, the .xvii. ſomwhat drifelyng raine, becauſe of the coniunccion of Venus and Luna, in Piſces, the xviii. daye colde and cloudy, the moſt part of al the daye and nyght alſo, the .xix. daye fayre, and temperate wether, the .xx. alſo fayre and ſomewhat enclyned to ſwete rayne, The .xxii. the ſame weather, the .xxiii. drie temperate weather, the .xxiiii. day a merely fayre daye. The .xxv. in the mornyng a fayre daye, but after colde and cloudy, The .xxvi wyndy and fayre, wether, the xxvii. cloudy and temperate weather, the xxviii. fayre wether, but ſomwhat windy, and cloudy, becauſe of the ſextile aſpect of Saturnus, and Mercu, the .xxix. a fayre and hote wether all the nyghte longe, becauſe of the coniunction of Mars, and Luna, in Virgo. The .xxx. day
in the mornynge ſome what wyndye, and after noone ſometyme ſwete ſhouers, but moſt part fayre weather.

div.head: ¶ Maye.
div.p:
THe fyrſte daye a fayre temperate day, the ſeconde daye cloudye and ſomewhat enclyned to moyſture, but it is lyke to holde vp, notwythſtanding, becauſe the ſignificatours of this rayne be in temperate manſions, and the mone alſo. The thyrd daye fayre wether and windy, becauſe of the coniuncion of Iupiter and Luna, in Libra an ayry ſigne. The .iiii. ſomwhat ruddye and ſomtyme raine. The .v. day cold, becauſe of the coniuncion of Saturnus, and Venus in the ſygne of Aries: The .vi. windy and rainy weather, becauſe of the quart aſpecte of Mars and Mercurius and the ſextyle aſpecte of Venus and Mercurius the ſayde .vi daye. The .vii. wyndy and cloudy, tyll nyghte, but in the nyghte about eyghte of the clocke ſomewhat fayre weather, and about ten of the clocke ſomewhat enclined to moyſture. The eight day ſomewhat fayre wether, the .ix. day cloudy weather, and the tenth day in the mornynge ſomewhat inclyned to moyſture, but at after noone
ſpecially towardes night fayre weather, and ſomewhat wyndy. The .xi. daye ſwete ſhoures of rayne. The .xii. daye in the after none fayre wether. The .xiii. day faire and wyndy. The .xiiii. day red white cloudes, ſometyme ſome moyſture The .xv. daye wyndye, wyth ſometymes rayne a lytle in a quantitye. The .xvi. daye colde and cloudy wyth cloudes troublyng the heauen lyke to brynge ſome rayne, but it wyll holde vp as it is aforeſayed. The xvii. a fayre daye the .xviii. daye ſomwhat fayre wether. The .xix. daye ſome wynde and rayne. The .xx. day fayre wether, but towardes nyght cloudy, the .xxi. daye becauſe of the oppoſition of Iupiter, and Venus in Aries and Libra, a fayre temperate day with whyte cloudes ſparkled about the heauen. The .xxii. day cloudy The .xxiii. day colde and cloudye alſo, becauſe of the ſextyle aſpecte Saturne, and Sol. The .xxiiii. day cloudy and ſomwhat inclyned to moyſture. The .xxv. day cloudy, but about thre of the clocke at after noone it wyl ſomewhat breake vp. The .xxvi. in the afternoone wyndye and merely fayre wether, the .xxvii. a afayre daye, and the .xxviii. daye alſo the xxix. cloudye. The thyrtye daye a metely fayre daye. The .xxxi. day fayre wether
and wyndye.

div.head: ¶ Iune.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day a fayre hote daye becauſe of the quarte aſpecte of Mars, and Sol. The ſeconde alſo the ſame wether, the thyrde daye wyndy and cloudy. The fourth day a fayre day, the .v. day a fayre daye and wyndye, the vi. day enclyned to moyſture, the ſeuenth day inclyned to wynde, the .viii. day ſome what inclyned to rayne, the ninthe fayre wether, and ſomwhat wyndye, the tenth daye in the fore none wyndye, the .xi. in the after noone fayre temperat wether. The .xii. wyndy and cloudy, the .xiii. daye cloudy, the fyftene daye ſwete ſhouers of ſmal rayne, but towardes night, and all nyght longe it wil be fayre and breake vp The .xvi. day cloudy, the .xvii. wyndye becauſe of the coniunction of Luna, and Mercurius in Gemini, the .xviii. a fayre temperate day, the nyntene a colder day then before, and cloudy alſo, the .xx. in the mornynge fayre wether, and alſo windy. The .xxi. daye cloudye, the .xxii. towardes night wyndye, but all the mooſt parte of the day metely fayre, the .xxiii. day ſomewhat cloudy wether, the .xxiiii.
daye enclyned to moyſture, the .xxv. daye whyte and red cloudes ſparkled aboute the ſkye wythwynd, bringing with them ſome rayne. The .xxvi cloudye, and colder then before. The .xxvii. a fayre wyndye daye, and the .xxviii. alſo. The .xxix. ſome what cloudy. The .xxx. fayre wether.

div.head: ¶ Iuly.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day cloudy, the ſeconde daye cloudy, and that becauſe of the quart aſpecte of Saturnus, and Mercurius, the .iii. daye a fayre day all the fore none, but in the afternoone cloudy. The fourthe in the after noone ſomewhat rainye, and towardes nyghte fayre wether, the .v. a fayre daye, but bycauſe of the ſextyle aſpect of Saturnus and Venus, the heauen ſhalbe ouercaſte with cloudes lyke to brynge ſome raine, but notwithſtanding it wyll be as a fore ſayde a fayre daye. The ſyxte a metely fayre weather, The ſeuenth metely temperate wether, the eyght day a fayre day with great wynde, and whyte cloudes couering almoſt the heauens, and this becauſe of the quart aſpecte of Soll, and Iupiter, and Mercurius, quarte aſpect to Iupiter alſo. The ix. a fayre daye, and a hoate, but that temperatly, becauſe of
the applycation of Luna to Satourne. The tenth day a metely fayre day in the afternone. The xi. ſomwhat enclined to moyſture, and the .xii. daye alſo, the .xiii. ſome rayne is lyke to happen, but the moſt of the weather ſhalbe temperatlye cloudy: the .xiiii daye in the afternoone cloudye: the .xv. temperate weather and cloudes in the ſkye lyke vnto the ſkales of yron: the .xvi. day fayre temperate wether: The .xvii. ſomewhat fayre weather, the .xviii. daye cloudy: the xix. day a fayre daye and ſomewhat wyndy: The .xx. daye ſomewhat moyſte weather: The .xxi. daie temperate weather, the .xxiii. day temperate wether, the .xxiiii. a fayre hotte daye ſpecially in the after noone, the .xxv. in the mornynge windye, the .xxvi. fayre wether: the .xxvii. a farie dai, the .xxviii. ſomwhat cloudy, but drye wether, the .xxix. fayre wether: the .xxx. wyndye: The .xxxi. ſomewhat enclyned to dryſſynge ſwete rayne.

div.head: ¶Auguſt.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day fayre wether becauſe of the application of Mars to Iupiter in the ſygne of Libra, the ſeconde daye cloudy all the moſte parte of the daye, but at nyghte fayre cleare wether,
the ninth day fayre in the morning ſpecially, and almoſt all day, the fourth in the after none enclyned to ſom rain, the fyfte ſomewhat enclyned to moyeſture, the ſyxte a fayre day, and whityſhe redde cloudes ſparkled about the heauens, and ſome tyme not withſtandynge cloudy, and that becauſe of aquarte aſpect betwixt Luna and Mars, and of a corporal coniunccion of Saturnus, and Luna, the ſeuenth day fayre weather, and wyndy, the .viii. day ſomewhat fayre wether, the nynth at after noone fayre and hote, the tenth cloudi, the .xi. a metely fayre daye, the .xii. a fayre temperate wyndy day becauſe of the ſextyle aſpect of Sol and Iupiter, the .xiii. a temperate dai, the .xiiii. in the mornyng about vii. a clocke fayre, but a bout .ix. a clocke ſome what enclyned to rayne, and after noone fayre wether, the .xv. ſomewhat enclyned to cloudynes, the .xvi. a temperate wether, the ſeuentene fayre and hote wether, the .xviii. fayre temperate wether, the .xix. wyndy, the twentye cloudye, the .xxi. daye fayre and temperate wether, the .xxii. daye a fayre daye, the xxiii. daye a fayre daye, becauſe the ſextyle aſpect of Sol and Mars, the xxiiii.
cloudy, & lyke to rayn, the .xxv. ſomwhat enclined to moiſture, the .xxvi. windy, the xxvii. cloudy, but towardes nighte, fayre wether, the .xxviii. ſomwhat enclyned to wynde, the .xxix. ſomewhat more cloudy then before, the .xxx. metely fayre, the xxxi. fayre and hotte.

div.head: ¶September.
div.p:
THe fyrſte day ſomwhat wyndy, the ſeconde daye cloudy, and cold wether, the thyrde daye a temperate daye ſomwhat cloudy lyke to rayne, but it wyll holde vp as before ſayde, the .iiii. fayre wether, but ſomtyme red cloudes, bringynge with them ſome rayne, the .v. day metely fayre wether, and temperate and drye, the .vi. cloudy, the .vii. faire and temperate, the .viii. metely fayre, the .ix. fayre, and that in a temperate manſion, alſo the .x. the ſame wether, the .xi. cloudy, the .xii. fayre becauſe of the quart aſpect of Mars to Luna, and the ſextyle of Venus to Iupiter, the .xiii. a faire tē perate daye, the .xiiii. fayre and wyndye, and that becauſe of a ſextyle betwyxte Mars and Mercurius. The .xv. fayre, the xvi. colde and cloudy, the .xvii. ſomewhat inclined to moiſture, the .xviii. fayre temperate
wether, becauſe of the coniunccion of Luna, and Iupiter in Scorpio the houſe of Mars, the .xix. wyndye, the xx. a fayre daye becauſe of the corporall coniuncion of Luna and Mars in Scorpio, with ſometymes red cloudes, brynging with them ſome rayne, the .xxi. cloudy, the .xxii. ſomwhat windy, the .xxiii. tyl it be paſt thre of the clocke in the after none windy, but afterwarde becauſe of the ſunnes oppoſition wyth Saturnus, colde and cloudye, the .xxiiii. daye ſomewhat enclyned to moyſture, the .xxv. fair wether, the .xxvi. colde and cloudye, the twenty and ſeuen metely fayre. The xxviii. temperate wether, the .xxix. temperate and windy, the .xxx. fayre.

div.head: ¶October.
div.p:
THe fyrſt daye metely fayre wether the .ii. daye enclyned to moyſture. The .iii. a temperate daye, the .iiii. temperate, but ſomwhat cloudi, becauſe of the trynall aſpecte of Saturnus, and Mars in fiery ſignes, the .v. a temperat daye, the ſyxte metely farre weather, the eyght day ſomewhat temperate, and towardes
nyght wyndy, the tenthe deye a temperat day, and blacke cloudes lyke to brynge ſome rayne, but it ſhall holde vp, becauſe of Saturne and Venus, the ſeconde ſignificatoures of this moyſture, be both in the temperate Manſions, the tenth metely temperate, the eleuenth day fayre wether, the twelueth becauſe of the ſextyle aſpecte of Mercurius and Mars, one in ayrye ſygne, an other, beyng in a fyrye ſygne. The thyrtenedaye colde and cloudye, the fourtenth temperate, with an inclinacion to moyſture, the fyftenth fayre in the after noone, the ſyxtene enclyned to moyſture. The .xvii. ſomewhat enclyned to droughte aboue hed, theightene toward euening, fayre whyte and rede cloudes, wyth weather alſo, the nynetene a fayre daye, the twenty daye metely fayre weather. The .xxi. daye temperate weather, the .xxii. temperatly wyndye, The .xxiii. fayre, and ſome what wyndye, the .xxiiii. in the mornynge fayre, and in the euenynge cloudes lyke to rayne, but it wyll holde vp becauſe Venus the ſignificatrix of thys rayne, is a good temperate manſion, the xxv. fayre and wyndye, the xxvi. fayre wether til two a clocke in the
afternoone, but afterwarde very colde and cloudy, the .xxvii. a fayre temperate day, the xxviiii. great wyndes, and whyte cloudes about the heauens, the .xxix. day towardes nyghte windye, the .xxx. greate wyndes, becauſe of the coniuncion of Mercuri and Iupiter, the .xxxi. cloudy

div.head: ¶Nouember.
div.p:
THe fyrſt daye fayre wether, the .ii. cloudy about noone, tyll three a clocke, and then metely fayre weather, the .iii. day, becauſe of the coniuncion of Mercurius and Soll in a moyſte ſygne, and a moyeſt manſion alſo ſignifyeth rayne with ſome wind, the .iiii. cloudy, the .v. and ſyre fayre weather, the .vii. fayre and temperat, the eight temperat, and in dede neyther fayre nor foule, the ninth mylde rayne, becauſe of the coniuncion of Iupiter, & Venus in Scorpio, a moyſt ſigne, and a moyſt manſion alſo, the .x. day raine & hayle, or els ſome ſnow withal, becauſe of the quart of Saturnus and Mars in moſt manſions, the ſame wether moſt part of the next daye, the .xii. day ſomwhat enclyned to gentle and ſmal rain. The .xiii. day the ſame wether, the .xiiii. cloudy. The .xv. enclyned
to moyeſture. The .xvi. cloudy in the afternoone. The .xvii. fayre weather and froſte. The .xviii. a fayre drye daye from rayne. The .xix. cloudy, becauſe of the trinal aſpect of Saturnus and Sol. The xx. in the after none lyke to rayne, but it wyl holde vp. The .xxi. ſomwhat cloudye, The .xxii. fayre in the fore noone, but in the after none windye, the .xxiii. cloudye, the .xxiiii fayre wether, the .xxv. cloudy, and as thoughe it woulde rayne, but it wyll hold vp, becauſe Saturne, and Venus (whoſe tryne aſpect cauſeth the wether aforeſayde) be in fiery ſingnes and temperate manſions, the .xxvi. fayre, the xxvii cloudy, the .xxviii. metely fayre, the xxix. ſomwhat cloudy, ye .xxx. metely fayre

div.head: ¶December.
div.p:
THe fyrſt day colde and rayne wythal, becauſe of the quart aſpect of Saturnus, and Mercurius in a moyſt manſion. The ſeconde daye ſome what enclyned to moyſture, the thyrde fayre weather, and whyte cloudes ſparkled about the heauens, the fourth fayre and temperate wether with ſome wynde the fyueth ſomewhat enclyned to moyſture, the ſyxe in the morning fayre and
all the mooſte parte of the daye cloudye and very colde, the ſeuenth wyndye, the eyght in the after none metely fayre, the nyght ſomwhat windy, the tenthe more windy, in eſpecially at after noone, the eleuenth a metely fayre day about none but afterward cloudy, the twelueth day ſomwhat enclyned to moyſture: The thyrtenth day metely fayre wether, but ſomwhat to much enclined to moyſture, the .xiiii. day cloudy. The fyftenth windy in the afternoone, the .xvi. a fayre drye day, but toward night colde and cloudy, the .xvii. day ſomewhat fayre wether, the xviii. colde, cloudy and rayne with ſome ſnowe, becauſe of the quart aſpecte of Sol to Saturnus, and a ſextyle of Mars to Saturnus, and a quarte of Saturnus to Venus. The .xix. day metely faire temperate wether, with winde, about ten of the clock, the .xx. dai cold and cloudy, the xxi. ſomwhat windy, and ſome rayn. The xxii. day fair temperate wether, the .xxiii. ſomewhat wyndye, the .xxiiii. in the mornynge fayre and windy, but afterwarde cloudy weather, the .xxv. a fayre colde day, the .xxvi. day cloudy, the .xxvii. daye fayre and temperate, the .xxviii. day metely
fayre with oftentymes ſweete ſhowers, and a lytle wynde. The .xxix. daye windy, but after noone cloudy, the .xxx. a fayre daye. The .xxxi. daye enclyned to coldneſſe and moyeſture.

div.head: ¶ Of thinfirmities that ſhalbe this preſnte yeare.
div.p:
FIrſt Mercuri Lord of the houſe of diſeaſes, in the fyrſt beginnīg of the fyrſt quarter, beyng in the ſygne of Piſces his fal, and in the ſecond cadent from the aſcendent, ſignifyeth that men ſhal haue infirmities in their ſhynne bones, ſecrete places, and Belies, and theſe diſeaſes ſhall happen moſt vpon boyes, and olde women about the age of .lx. and vpon the learned ſort of men alſo. Iupiter lord of the houſe of infirmities direct, and in the aſcendent of the ſeconde quarter of the yere, ſignifieth that ther ſhalbe no infirmities in that quarter, but peynes in the yies of men, and about theyr knees alſo, which diſeaſes ſhal happen moſt vpon noble men, and vpō youre noble maidens alſo. Moreouer Saturnus,
beyng Lorde of the houſe of infyrmities, in the thirde quarter, and impedite in Aries, and in the ninth houſe ſignifyeth there ſhalbe quarterne agues, which ſhalbe great, and reumes ſtyllynge out of mennes heddes into theyr Lightes, and trembling of Sinewes, and peynes in theyr knees, and yies, through corrupte bloude, becauſe of Mars in the ſygne of Mars. Finally, Venus in the fourth quarter, is figured Ladye of the ſyxte houſe, beyng in Sagittarius in the aſcendent alſo, ſignifyeth that men ſhal haue no infirmities, but ſuch as happen throughe ſurfettes of drinking, and immoderate venerous actes.

div.head: ¶ Of warres, and contencions.
div.p:
MArs in a humain ſigne in the .viii houſe, ſygnifyeth that mortall war ſhal happen amongeſt men, and the more becauſe of his retrogradacion this euyl effect, and diſpoſition ſhal be more vehement, and this ſhal appeare more in the Southe partes, and in the Eaſte partes, then in any other places.
Mars alſo in the ſecond quarter of the yeare aforeſayd, and in the .xxvii. of Virgo in the .xii. houſe, the houſe of enemies ſingnifyeth warre and bloudſhed, Mars in the ſygne of Scorpio, and in the .iiii. houſe of the heauens, ſingnifyeth that many ſhalbe ſlayne with the ſweard, and that in the .iii. quarter of the yere aforeſayd. Finally Mars in the .iiii. quarter, and in the reuolucion therof in the ſeconde houſe, the houſe of ſubſtaūce, ſingnifieth that there ſhalbe great ſpoyle of the ignoble people by ſodiours, and men of war, becauſe he is in Aquari, whyche ſygne is the fall of the Sunne, and the houſe of cloudy Saturne, which planet ſingnifyeth diggers, and deluers of the yearth, and ſuch ignoble people, and perſons.

div.head: ¶ Of Cattall, and all other thynges, whiche ſerue for victualles, as wheat, barley, beanes, and ſuche lyke.
div.p:
FIrſt Mars beyng Lord of the .viii houſe impedite, ſyngnifyeth that in the fyrſt quarter of the yere aforeſayd ſhepe ſhall dye much, and in the
ſeconde quarter alſo. Moreouer in the third quarter. Mars in Scorpio, ſingnifieth that ſhepe ſhal not die, in the Reuoluciō of the ſaid quarter, and in the .iiii. and laſt quarter, Mars in the .ii. houſe, ſignifyeth that ſhepe ſhal nat dye, but very fewe. Venus in the fyrſt quarters, Reuolucion in the ſeconde houſe, Retrograde, ſingnifyeth that Woll ſhalbe but of a metely lowe price in that quarter, and Venus in the ſeconde quarter, and in the eyght of Taurus, and in the eyght houſe of enemyes, ſignifieth that Woll ſhalbe hygher of price muche more then before it was in the fyrſte quarter, And Venus in the ſeuenth of Virgo, and the fyrſt houſe of the heauens, at the Reuolucion of the ſeconde quarter ſingnifyeth that woll ſhalbe very deare, and higher of pryce then before. Moreouer in the fourth quarter of the Reuoluriō of the yeare aforeſaid Venus peregrine in the aſcendent, ſingnifyeth that there ſhalbe greate plentye of woll emongeſt men, and it ſhall not be deare. Venus Lady of Taurus retrograde, ſingnifieth that Kyne or calues ſhall not proſper in the fyrſte quarter but metely ſo, but in
the next quarter, kyne and calues ſhalbe of a good and hyghe pryce and ſo alſo in the thyrd quarter of the yeare aforſaid, but in the .iiii. quarter Venus in the aſcendent, and impedite out of al her dignities, ſingnifyeth that the pryce of Oxen, Kyne, and Calues, ſhal fal in the ſaid quarter: Wheate in the firſt quarter lowe of pryce, and in the ſeconde quarter within the whiche harueſt falleth no greate aboundaunce of Wheate, and in that quarter it ſhalbe but of a low price. Moreouer in the .iii. quarter, ſpeciallye ii. wekes afore Michelmas, wheate ſhall be good cheape, and in the fourth quarter lowe of pryce wyll wheate be. Barley ſhalbe of a metely lowe pryce in the fyrſte quarter of the yeare Barley alſo in the ſeconde quarter of the yeare of a metely lowe pryce, but in this ſeconde quarter in the whiche harueſt falleth there ſhall therof be good plenty, Barley in the thyrde quarter ſhall be good cheape ii. wekes afore Michelmaſſe, but about fourtene dayes afore Hallontide deare agayne, but that dearthe ſhall not longe continue. Barley in the fourthe quarter of the yeare metely good chepe, and lytle of it amongeſt men. Beanes
in the fyrſte quarter of the yeare aforeſayd good cheape, and of lowe pryce.

Beanes in the ſeconde quarter, of metely reaſonable price, and that ſomwhat of the higheſt, and of them great plentye in this ſeconde quarter Beanes of a metelye good pryce in the thirde quarter. Beanes in the .iiii. quarter good cheape.
And generally for mooſte thynges neceſſary, this yeare wil be plentyfull ynoughe, ſpecially all the Somer, for all the chief fruites of the earth.
